Authors: Kamlofsky J.A., Naidoo N., Bright G., Bergamini M.L., Zelasco J., Ansaldo F., Stopforth R.
Title: Semi-autonomous robot control system with an improved 3d vision scheme for search and rescue missions. A joint research collaboration between South Africa and Argentina
Source title: Advances in Science, Technology and Engineering Systems
Affiliations: Universidad Abierta Interamericana (UAI), CAETI, Buenos Aires, C1270AAH, Argentina; University of KwaZulu-Natal (UKZN), Mechatronics and Robotics Research Group (MR2G), Durban, 4000, South Africa; Universidad de Buenos Aires (UBA), Facultad de Ingeniería, Buenos Aires, C1063ACV, Argentina
Authors with affiliations: Kamlofsky, J.A., Universidad Abierta Interamericana (UAI), CAETI, Buenos Aires, C1270AAH, Argentina; Naidoo, N., University of KwaZulu-Natal (UKZN), Mechatronics and Robotics Research Group (MR2G), Durban, 4000, South Africa; Bright, G., University of KwaZulu-Natal (UKZN), Mechatronics and Robotics Research Group (MR2G), Durban, 4000, South Africa; Bergamini, M.L., Universidad Abierta Interamericana (UAI), CAETI, Buenos Aires, C1270AAH, Argentina; Zelasco, J., Universidad de Buenos Aires (UBA), Facultad de Ingeniería, Buenos Aires, C1063ACV, Argentina; Ansaldo, F., Universidad de Buenos Aires (UBA), Facultad de Ingeniería, Buenos Aires, C1063ACV, Argentina; Stopforth, R., University of KwaZulu-Natal (UKZN), Mechatronics and Robotics Research Group (MR2G), Durban, 4000, South Africa
Abstract: Rescue operations require technology to assist the rescue process. The robotic technology in these missions is becoming very important. The important aspects investigated in this study are the integration of a mechatronic system that will allow for a robotic platform with a vision system. The research collaboration between Argentina and South Africa is discussed, with the correlating research areas that each country investigated. The study permitted the development and advancement of a search and rescue system for different robots (wayfarer and drones) with different vision capabilities. A novel and innovative vision approach is presented. © 2018 Advances in Science, Technology and Engineering Systems. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: 3D vision; Robotic navigation; Robotic vision; Search and rescue robots
Funding Details:
SA / 13/13

Department of Science and Technology, Republic of South Africa, DST

Ministerio de Ciencia, Tecnología e Innovación Productiva, MINCyT

Funding Text 1: Within the framework of the Scientific-Technological Cooperation Program between the Ministry of Science, Technology and Productive Innovation of the Argentine Republic (initials in Spanish: MINCyT) and the Department of Science and Technology of the Republic of South Africa (DST), the project called "Semi-Autonomous robots for SAR operations" was selected by the Bilateral Commission MINCYT-DST to be executed in the 2014-2016 triennium under code SA / 13/13.
Funding Text 2: The research presented in this paper is part of a joint collaboration between the University of KwaZulu-Natal, in South Africa, and the University of Buenos Aires, in Argentina. The authors wish to thank their respective governments for funding this research and for making the collaboration possible.

Authors: Berrío Meneses V., Alzate Velásquez D.F., Ramón Valencia J.A., Ramón Valencia J.L.
Title: Optimization system of planning techniques in precision agriculture through drones [Sistema de optimización de las técnicas de planificación en agricultura de precisión por medio de drones]
Affiliations: GEI, PNUD, Bogotá, Colombia; CORPOICA, Bogotá, Colombia; Universidad de Pamplona, Colombia; Universidad El Bosque, Colombia
Authors with affiliations: Berrío Meneses, V., GEI, PNUD, Bogotá, Colombia; Alzate Velásquez, D.F., CORPOICA, Bogotá, Colombia; Ramón Valencia, J.A., Universidad de Pamplona, Colombia; Ramón Valencia, J.L., Universidad El Bosque, Colombia
Abstract: This work is intended to apply UAVs (Unmanned Aerial Systems) or drones to agriculture, with the purpose to measure some parameters and obtain other relevant information about the health of the crops, using less time and resources and in a efficiently way that allows the producers to take decisions and save money. For this, a potato crop (Solanum tuberosum) was selected, considering its importance for the national economy and culture, and the metrological and logistical procedures were defined to capture, using a fixed wing drone, high resolution multispectral imagery. To do this two cameras were used, a RGB (visible) and a NIR (Near Infrared), capturing the Blue, Green, Red and IR bands. This set of bands allow us to calculate the Normalized Vegetation Index or NDVI for the potato crop, and, through this index, define the differenced spectral response zones. To determine why there were zones with different spectral response or different NDVI values, a field observation were performed, obtaining that, where the index was medium or low (0.2 to 0.6) existed a problem in the crop health or the presence of another plants like grass or herbaceous, which compete with potato for water and sunlight. The results show that spectral response is a good indicator of vegetation characteristics and potential problems in crops, which make this technology viable as an alternative for monitoring and better planning of agriculture activities. © 2018.El presente trabajo se enfoca a la implementación de la tecnología de VANT (Vehículos aéreos no tripulados) o drones en la agricultura, con el fin de estimar parámetros del cultivo y obtener otra información relevante sobre su estado de salud, en menores tiempos y de forma más eficiente que permitan tomar decisiones que mejoran la rentabilidad de los agricultores. Para esto, se seleccionó un cultivo de interés nacional como es la papa (Solanum tuberosum) y sobre este se realizó el montaje metodológico y logístico para capturar, a través de un dron de ala fija, imágenes multiespectrales de alta resolución. Las imágenes fueron capturadas con dos cámaras, una RGB (Visible) y otra NIR (Infrarrojo cercano), las cuales capturan las bandas Verde-Azul-Rojo y Azul-Verde-IR (Infrarrojo cercano). Esta configuración de bandas permitió calcular el índice de vegetación de diferencia normalizada (NDVI) para el cultivo de papa, y a través del cálculo de este índice se definieron zonas de respuesta espectral diferenciada, las cuales fueron posteriormente verificadas en campo para establecer las causas de dicha respuesta espectral. Se encontró que en zonas de índices medios y bajos (0.2 a 0.6), era evidente algún problema de desarrollo en el cultivo o la presencia de especies invasoras. Los resultados obtenidos demuestran que la respuesta espectral permite identificar características de la vegetación y problemas en el cultivo, de tal forma que se evidencia la viabilidad técnica de esta herramienta tecnológica como alternativa para pequeños y grandes agricultores que permite optimizar el desarrollo de los sistemas productivos. © 2018.
Author Keywords: Agricultura de precisión; Drones; Drones; Imágenes multiespectrales; Multispectral imagery; NDVI; NDVI; Near infrared

Title: Technology of project time management
Affiliations: Department of Economics and Enterprise Management, Kazan National Research Technical University A.N. Tupolev - KAI, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Khusainov, Z.K., Department of Economics and Enterprise Management, Kazan National Research Technical University A.N. Tupolev - KAI, Russian Federation
Abstract: The article describes the technology of project time management under conditions of strict time constraints. The classification of the organization's employees is given within the framework of the article, assuming such types as: generator; operator; office drones; organizer, freelancer. Various conditions for project implementation are considered, which present the following situations: tasks are distributed only between department employees, with each work performed only by a specific employee; tasks are distributed only between employees of the department, but you can apply the method of teamwork on a specific task; tasks are distributed among employees, and there is also the opportunity to reduce the time of routine work due to the creativity of the generator; use all the possible levers of project management - the generator, freelancers, the joint work of several employees on one task. Based on an assessment of the feasibility of implementing all project tasks, the effect of differences in the different employees' performance during the execution of individual tasks is shown. The levers of project time management are determined - joint work of employees on separate stages, attraction of freelancers, reduction of time for accomplishing tasks. Variant calculations have been carried out, proving the effect of the integrated use of a wide range of levers to shorten the project time. © 2018.
Author Keywords: Critical path; Freelancer; Productivity; Project; Terms of the project

Title: Accuracy assessment of digital surface models based on a small format action camera in a north-East Hungarian sample area
Affiliations: Department of Physical Geography and Geoinformatics, University of Debrecen, Egyetem tér 1., Debrecen, 4032, Hungary
Authors with affiliations: Barkóczi, N., Department of Physical Geography and Geoinformatics, University of Debrecen, Egyetem tér 1., Debrecen, 4032, Hungary; Szabó, G., Department of Physical Geography and Geoinformatics, University of Debrecen, Egyetem tér 1., Debrecen, 4032, Hungary
Abstract: The use of the small format digital action cameras has been increased in the past few years in various applications, due to their low budget cost, flexibility and reliability. We can mount these small cameras on several devices, like unmanned air vehicles (UAV) and create 3D models with photogrammetric technique. Either creating or receiving these kind of databases, one of the most important questions will always be that how accurate these systems are, what the accuracy that can be achieved is. We gathered the overlapping images, created point clouds, and then we generated 21 different digital surface models (DSM). The differences based on the number of images we used in each model, and on the flight height. We repeated the flights three times, to compare the same models with each other. Besides, we measured 129 reference points with RTK-GPS, to compare the height differences with the extracted cell values from each DSM. The results showed that higher flight height has lower errors, and the optimal air base distance is one fourth of the flying height in both cases. The lowest median was 0.08 meter, at the 180 meter flight, 50 meter air base distance model. Raising the number of images does not increase the overall accuracy. The connection between the amount of error and distance from the nearest GCP is not linear in every case.
Author Keywords: Agisoft photo scan; Airborne imagery; Drone; DSM; Photogrammetry
Index Keywords: accuracy assessment; airborne sensing; database; digital terrain model; equipment; error correction; image analysis; numerical model; photogrammetry; three-dimensional modeling; unmanned vehicle; Hungary

Authors: Bacsardi L., Birkeland R., Hornig A., Shar M., Morrison B., Tsodikovich Y.
Title: Present and the Future of Space Internet: The Space Generation Perspective
Affiliations: University of Sopron, Bajcsy-Zs. u. 4, Sopron, H-9400, Hungary; Norwegian University of Science and Technology, Trondheim, Norway; University of Stuttgart, Stuttgart, Germany; International Space University, Strasbourg, France; Durham University, Durham, United Kingdom; Tel Aviv University, Tel Aviv, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Bacsardi, L., University of Sopron, Bajcsy-Zs. u. 4, Sopron, H-9400, Hungary; Birkeland, R., Norwegian University of Science and Technology, Trondheim, Norway; Hornig, A., University of Stuttgart, Stuttgart, Germany; Shar, M., International Space University, Strasbourg, France; Morrison, B., Durham University, Durham, United Kingdom; Tsodikovich, Y., Tel Aviv University, Tel Aviv, Israel
Abstract: During the Space Generation Congress 2015, held in Jerusalem, Israel, students and young professionals representing 14 countries participated in the Space Communication - Space Internet working group. The group investigated the possibilities, risks, and opportunities of using satellites, drones, and high-altitude balloons to provide widespread access to the internet. The group focused on one of the barriers for worldwide connectivity - the lack of economic viability for providing internet access using land infrastructure, and the possible solutions that will address this problem. As a result of these findings, the working group participants proposed several recommendations. These recommendations take into account the numerous challenges that come with developing air- and space-based internet access; whether it be by balloons, drones, satellites, or a combination of these. These challenges range from acquiring regulatory approval to technical and practical limitations, such as the potential for damage to property and issues related to orbital debris. Due to our group's consensus that worldwide internet availability would ultimately be beneficial, given both humanitarian and economic concerns for poor and wealthy nations alike, we propose 4 "game changing" ideas that have the potential to positively impact the space economy. We first suggest that market studies be conducted to illustrate demand for the service. With sufficient demand, a phased approach to the solution should then be instituted. We further propose that national governments, which currently are not involved in the projects, serve as anchor tenants and expedite regulatory processes. Finally, to ensure commercial sustainability, Internet Service Providers (ISPs) should be considered potential distribution partners for the system. Our article deals with the current status and the future of space-based internet services, and details our recommendations. © Copyright 2017, Mary Ann Liebert, Inc. 2017.
Author Keywords: internet providers; space communications; Space Generation Advisory Council; Space Generation Congress; space internet

Title: Applying the repertory grid method for technology forecasting: Civil unmanned aviation systems for Germany
Affiliations: University of Bayreuth, Department of Innovation and Dialogue Marketing, Universitätsstraße 30, Bayreuth, 95447, Germany; Brandenburg University of Technology Cottbus-Senftenberg, Department of Planning and Innovation Management, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Eimecke, J., University of Bayreuth, Department of Innovation and Dialogue Marketing, Universitätsstraße 30, Bayreuth, 95447, Germany; Baumert, K., Brandenburg University of Technology Cottbus-Senftenberg, Department of Planning and Innovation Management, Germany; Baier, D., University of Bayreuth, Department of Innovation and Dialogue Marketing, Universitätsstraße 30, Bayreuth, 95447, Germany
Abstract: Multistage expert surveys like the Delphi method are proven concepts for technology forecasting that enable the prediction of content-related and temporal development in fields of innovation (e.g., [1, 2]). Advantages of these qualitative multistage methods are a simple and easy to understand concept while still delivering valid results [3]. Nevertheless, the literature also points out certain disadvantages especially in large-scale technology forecasts in particularly abstract fields of innovation [4]. The proposed approach highlights the usefulness of the repertory grid method as an alternative for technology forecasting and as a first step for preference measurement. The basic approach from Baier and Kohler [5] is modified in-so-far that an online survey reduces the cognitive burden for the experts and simplifies the data collection process. Advantages over alternative approaches through its simple structure and through combining qualitative and quantitative methods are shown and an adaption on an actual field of innovation – civil drones in Germany – is done. The measurement of a common terminology for all experts minimizes misunderstandings during the interview and the achievement of an inter-individual comparable level of abstraction is forced by the laddering technique [6] during the interview.
Author Keywords: Civil drones; Innovative product development; Multistage expert surveys; Qualitative research; Quality requirements; Quantitative research; Repertory grid method; Technology forecasting

Title: Reforming the current regulatory framework for commercial drones: Retaining american businesses’ competitive advantage in the global economy
Source title: Northwestern Journal of International Law and Business
Affiliations: Northwestern University Pritzker School of Law, United States
Authors with affiliations: Chen, G.Y., Northwestern University Pritzker School of Law, United States
Abstract: The existing regulatory framework in the United States for unmanned aircraft systems (UAS, or drones) desperately needs updates in order to capitalize on the benefits of drones’ commercial usage. American lawmakers can draw inspiration from foreign lawmakers and regulatory bodies in Canada, Australia, and Asia in creating a sensible framework that integrates the use of commercial drones.1 A new regulatory framework customized to address the different usage priorities of commercial drones will unleash American businesses’ potential to utilize drones in various commercial operations and to stay competitive in the fight for market share in capturing the multiple billion dollar global drones market. © 2017 by Gina Y. Chen.

Title: Autonóm repülo robotok alkalmazása vízelvezeto csatornák felügyeletére [Using autonomous flying robots to monitor canals]
Affiliations: Subotica Tech - College of Applied Sciences, Marka Oreškovica 16, Subotica, 24000, Serbia; Faculty of Engineering, University of Pécs, Hungary
Authors with affiliations: Szabó, A., Subotica Tech - College of Applied Sciences, Marka Oreškovica 16, Subotica, 24000, Serbia, Faculty of Engineering, University of Pécs, Hungary
Abstract: The weather change of the recent decades caused changes that can be felt in Vojvodina, too. In this economy which mostly relies on agriculture, farmlands are afflicted with floods one year and drought in another. To balance these, canal systems are already built. Because of the size of the canal network, its periodic monitoring requires huge amount of work and recourses. Our research investigates possibility of aerial monitoring of regional irrigation and drainage canals using drones. Autonomous flying robots are becoming more and more popular in recent years. This is happening because the technology they are based on is getting less expensive, quadcopters have broken into the consumer market, so the manufacturing costs are constantly decreasing. This enables them to be used both in research and in the industry without having to pay huge amounts of money. In this research, a commercially available quadcopter has been used to monitor water canals around the city. By design, the device has a built-in camera and wireless internet capabilities. These allow to take photos, record video and upload them to the controlling device. It is also possible to stream the live video to the device in real time. The controlling device can be a personal computer, a tablet or even a mobile phone. It is planned that the client software be extended with capability to upload video and photos to the cloud for later reference. Also, other sensors can be added to the device, too.
Author Keywords: Cloud; Mapping; Monitoring; Quadcopter; Robot; Water

Title: The once and future high-tech hospital
Authors with affiliations: Parsons, J.
Abstract: Grandview Medical Center in Birmingham was retained by Community Health Systems and was restructured as a leading digital hospital. To help make Grandview's comeback story a reality, Birmingham-based Brasfield & Gorrie, the original project's general contractor, was retained. Contractors would have to perform interior fit-up work in concert with tear-outs of some finished spaces to accommodate the medical specialties of a tertiary care hospital as well as to satisfy building codes that had changed significantly since 2003. By retro-commissioning existing mechanical, electrical and plumbing systems early in the restart phase, contractors confirmed that most installed equipment could serve the repurposed hospital. This process eliminated both uncertainty and potential costs from the project budget. Project team members used building information modeling to digitize original construction drawings while also providing a base for incorporating programming-related layout and system infrastructure changes developed by lead architect ESA Architects of Nashville. Contractors also used drone-mounted cameras to inspect 250,000 sq ft of the hospital's decade-old glass and precast skin exterior to identify areas in need of repair. Despite the unusual set of challenges, the hospital and related projects achieved their expected levels of quality, for a total cost of $280 million.

Title: Reality-capture technology AIDS brownfield redevelopment planning
Affiliations: Develpoment of Verticals, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sawyer, T., Develpoment of Verticals, United States
Abstract: the city manager and the town?s consulting engineers in Coatesville, Pa., are using 3D reality capture to help prospective developers. April Barkasi, founder and president of Cedarville Engineering Group LLC, Pottstown, has implemented the idea of using Bentley System?s ContextCapture to build a 3D digital Terrain model of a brownfield site as the basis for a redevelopment concept plan. a drone captures more than 750 aerial photos of ?The Flats?, a rugged, 30-acre former steel-mill site. The ContextCapture software processes the drone?s photos, combining them with old survey data and other photos to create a detailed model of the site The model includes a significant amount of stockpiled clean fill, which is a good thing for any redevelopment deal.

Title: Obama signs 14-Month FAA extension
Authors with affiliations: Ichniowski, T.
Abstract: President Obama has signed a measure to extend Federal Aviation Administration programs, including airport construction grants, through September 2017. The legislation, which the president signed on July 15, gained final congressional approval on July 13, when the Senate passed it by a strong 89-4 vote. Under the new statute, FAA funding continues at 2016 levels. FAA's Airport Improvement Program construction grants are frozen at 2016's $3.35-billion authorization, subject to annual appropriations. The legislation also contains policy provisions, including language dealing with unmanned aircraft, or drones.
Index Keywords: Unmanned aerial vehicles (UAV); Airport construction; Airport improvement programs; Federal Aviation Administration; Unmanned aircrafts; Air transportation

Title: FAA issues new rules for commercial drones
Affiliations: ENR.com, Washington, DC, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ichniowski, T., ENR.com, Washington, DC, United States
Abstract: The Federal Aviation Administration has approved its first set of regulations governing the use of small, unmanned aircraft systems, or drones, in construction or other commercial operations. The new rule, which FAA and its parent, the U.S. Dept. of Transportation, unveiled on June 21, covers drones weighing less than 55 lbs. It limits UAS operations to altitudes of 400 ft and speeds of 100 mph (87 knots) during the daytime and with anti-collision lights, at twilight. Operators also would be required to keep the drones within their visual line of sight. Under the rule, which takes effect 60 days after it is published in the Federal Register, drones cannot be operated over people, unless they are taking part directly in the flight or under a covered structure or in a covered stationary vehicle, FAA says. Operators must be at least 16 years old, have a remote pilot airman certificate with a small UAS rating or be directly supervised by someone who holds that certificate. The Senate in April approved its FAA reauthorization measure, which has language dealing with drone safety and delineating federal and state roles in overseeing the devices.
Index Keywords: Aircraft accidents; Collision avoidance; Drones; Anti-collision light; Commercial operation; Federal Aviation Administration; Small UAS; Unmanned aircraft system; Visual line; Unmanned aerial vehicles (UAV)

Title: Immunooptidrone - a case study on the general suitability of purpose of abstract evolutionary approaches

Abstract: The work investigates the general suitability of purpose of abstract evolutionary approaches by investigating the issues involved with re-factoring an existing, gene expression programming based, drone control system into an immunologically based general purpose optimization system. The re-purposed model is investigated regarding its suitability suitable for use in clonal expansion based optimization contexts made possible due to being freed from the physical constraints of real world drone hardware. © MIR Labs.

Title: Leading UK-based design firm releases building kits for African droneports

Abstract: Foster + Partners from London, UK, has launched a building kit for landing sites needed for a fleet of drones proposed to deliver medical and other supplies to remote African locations. Authors: Duvillard-Monternier S., Donnot J., Gilles P.-Y.
Title: Requirements of cognitive, psychomotor and interactive-social abilities for French remotely piloted aircraft systems operators [Quelles sont les aptitudes cruciales pour les postes d'opérateurs de systèmes de drones «Harfang»?]
Affiliations: Centre Psyclé (Psychologie de la Connaissance, du Langage et de l'Émotion), AMU (Aix-Marseille Université), Aix-en-Provence Cedex 01, 13621, France; Centre de Recherche de l'Armée de l'Air (CReA), Salon de Provence, 13661, France
Authors with affiliations: Duvillard-Monternier, S., Centre Psyclé (Psychologie de la Connaissance, du Langage et de l'Émotion), AMU (Aix-Marseille Université), Aix-en-Provence Cedex 01, 13621, France, Centre de Recherche de l'Armée de l'Air (CReA), Salon de Provence, 13661, France; Donnot, J., Centre Psyclé (Psychologie de la Connaissance, du Langage et de l'Émotion), AMU (Aix-Marseille Université), Aix-en-Provence Cedex 01, 13621, France, Centre de Recherche de l'Armée de l'Air (CReA), Salon de Provence, 13661, France; Gilles, P.-Y., Centre Psyclé (Psychologie de la Connaissance, du Langage et de l'Émotion), AMU (Aix-Marseille Université), Aix-en-Provence Cedex 01, 13621, France
Abstract: The current study focuses on the profiles required to become Remotely Piloted Aircraft Systems (RPAS) operators in the French Air Force. The Harfang system is operated by three different specialists located into a Ground Control Station. The Pilot Operator controls for the aircraft and sensors, the Imagery Analyst analyses the full motion video in real time and the Tactical Coordinator manages both team and missions. This system is in charge of missions relative to Intelligence, Surveillance and Reconnaissance (ISR) collection. In order to anticipate the development of a specific RPAS operators' career field in the French Air Force, a standardized selection is needed to propose the most appropriate applicants to the training. This selection requires to identify the best predictors for success. We ran two job analyses. The first analysis, directed to the work station, led to describe activities for each of the three specialists. The second analysis, directed to the individual himself, led to collect the level of complexity for required cognitive, psychomotor and interactive-social abilities related to the previously identified activities. Interviews were used to perform the job analysis focused on the work situation, and an adapted version of F-JAS (Fleishman - Job Analysis Survey) was developed to assess levels of abilities required for activities. The whole population of Harfang operators (N = 30) was solicited for the study. Results showed the optimal profile for each specialist in terms of highest assessed abilities for cognitive, psychomotor and interactive-social domain. Thus, the profile of Pilot Operators is focused on cognitive abilities and especially on attentional abilities. The profile of Tactical Coordinators is balanced between cognitive and interactive-social abilities whereas the profile of Imagery Analysts is highly specialized in cognitive abilities. Results are discussed according to the literature. The methodology used in the current study consisted in an adaptation of the F-JAS. The association of abilities to the operators' activities offers the possibility to update or to add some new activities like the armed capability. Another strength of this methodology is the possibility to be applied on other job's in aeronautics. By example, fighter pilots (e.g. Rafale) and airlift pilots (e.g. A400M) could be the next studied populations. In fact, training of RPAS operators as well as training of pilots have to be adaptive to keep connected with both the RPA systems in constant technical evolution and the new generations of aircraft (e.g. glass-cockpit generation).
Author Keywords: Abilities; Aeronautics; Job analysis; Military; Selection; Teleoperation

Title: Repairs under way at corvette museum after sinkhole swallows cars
Authors with affiliations: McCampbell, C.
Abstract: Repair works were undertaken at the Corvette Museum, where eight collector cars were swallowed suddenly by a sinkhole. Another hole was dug at the side and a crane was deployed to retrieve the swallowed cars. Construction, engineering and geological experts were present at the Bowling Green, Ky., facility after the incident on February 12, 2014, examining the building and the sinkhole, which were around 60 ft to 70 ft wide and about 60 ft deep. The recovery team will stabilize the building, remove the cars, two of which were covered by dirt in the pit, refill the chasm, and repair the floor, a 40-ft-dia section of which fell as the sinkhole opened up, leaving electrical and communication wires dangling over the hole. Stabilization of the circular 12-story atrium was scheduled to be completed in early March 2014.
Author Keywords: Corvette museum; Drones; Matthew; Murphy & daniel; Scott; Sinkhole; Western kentucky university

Title: Robots on the jobsite advancing in construction
Authors with affiliations: Rubenstone, J.
Abstract: The Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency's 'Robotics Challenge' competition was the first such effort by the agency at exploring how engineers could apply the repetitive and algorithm-driven advantages of modern robotics to the varied unpredictable environments of disaster zones Along with real-world working situations, such as construction jobsites. DARPA, a division of the US Department of Defense, focused on funding the development of emerging technologies, announced the challenge after the March 2011 disaster at the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear powerplant in Japan. A robot from the Japan-based SCHAFT team was the highest-scoring entry in the competition, which scored 27 out of the 32 points awarded in the tests. Some of the other teams looked at DARPA's short, one-year lead time for the contest and chose to focus on a robot for specific tasks, rather than a robot that performed multiple tasks. The top-scoring teams from the December competition made efforts to improve their creations for the next round of trials to be held in December 2014 or in early 2015.

Title: Fluidic flight controls for aircraft?
Abstract: Researchers at several UK universities are involved in a project to study if fluidic controls, those based on the Coanda Effect, could exert control forces on an aircraft, Demon UAV. The UK team based their new drone on a previously successful UAV, the Eclipse, but had to increase size by 15% and add several new features. The Demon's airframe was constructed of carbon-fiber composites, which keeps the aircraft light and responsive to small control forces. All fabrics and tapes were 0.25-mm thick, giving a good compromise between layup times and being able to adjust thicknesses. The trailing edge of the Demon's wings were modified to carry both conventional and fluidic ailerons and elevators. The APU provides air for the wing's fluidic controls at 0.5-bar gauge and 80°C and the thrust-vectoring controls use air pressurized to 4-bar gauge and 250°C bled from the main engine.

Title: Unmanned military aircraft: Attack of the drones
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: USAF plots unmanned flight career path
Authors with affiliations: Harrington, C.
Abstract: The US Air Force (USAF) is planning to significantly increase its unmanned aircraft pilot training, to meet a goal of deploying 50 combat air patrols a day throughout the day by 2011. The USAF's unmanned aerial systems (UAS) conducts 28 combat air patrols in a day in Iraq and Afghanistan. The new US training approach involves, developing a new career field, which is specifically focused on unmanned aerial systems. The main objective of the program is, to train USAF personnel, to fly aerial drones through specialized training. The training program will involve UAS pilots from the USAF's traditional undergraduate pilot training (UPT). The plan is to develop and validate training programs that prepare non-UPT pilots for wartime UAS duty. The USAF is also expected to maintain the highest levels of air force flight safety standards during such training programs.
Correspondence Address: Harrington, C., Washington, DC, United States

Title: Growler conducts first live AMRAAM firing
Authors with affiliations: Jennings, G.
Abstract: The US Navy (USN) announced on 31 July, 2008, that the Boeing EA-18G B Growler electronic warfare (EW) aircraft has conducted its first live firing of a Raytheon AIM-120 Advanced Medium Range Air-to-Air Missile (AMRAAM). The firing was conducted at the Naval Air Warfare Center Weapons Division, China Lake, California, US, on 23 July, 2008. The firing has emerged as one of the most significant events in the Growler's test program that released the first ordnance from the EA-18G aircraft. The Growler test team, comprising developmental and operational testers, executed a successful short, demonstrating a self-contained air-to-air capability, as part of the integrated test and evaluation of the aircraft. The aircraft first jammed the threat systems located at China Lake's Echo range, before engaging a Northrop Grumman BQM-74E target drone for conducting the test.
Correspondence Address: Jennings, G., London, United Kingdom

Title: US Army urges accelerated FCS production
Authors with affiliations: Harrington, C.
Abstract: US Army is increasing the production of Future Combat System (FCS) as it is confident that the system will save lives after observing its performance in a limited preliminary user test near Fort Bliss, Texas. Army officials tested the FCS 'Spin Out 1' kit during a training exercise, operating the network of weapon systems in a mock village between White Sands Missile range and Fort Bliss. FCS Spin Out 1 consists of a Non-Line-of Sight Launch System (NLOS-LS) for precision fires, a 'B-kit' computer system to share imagery, unattended sensors, an aerial drone known as the Class I Block 0 Micro Air Vehicle (MAV), and a ground-based robot known as the Small Unmanned Ground Vehicle. The precision fires of the NLOS-LS and the situational awareness provided by the MAV were particularly helpful in conducting operations in a crowded urban environment. The army has already begun shipping FCS 'spin-out' parts to Iraq and Afghanistan, deploying the FCS MAV with both an army and navy unit.
Correspondence Address: Harrington, C., Washington, DC, United States

Title: Satellite sensors zero in on resource and disaster planning
Authors with affiliations: Kincade, K.
Abstract: Advances in high-resolution satellite image processing and remote sensing capabilities have helped the environmental monitoring community to fight against natural and man-made disasters. Hyperspectral sensors from orbiting satellites provide multispectral data for further analysis of environmental conditions, land cover, and the impact of urban growth and related transportation development. Synthetic aperture radar (SAR) image can cover a wide area, the resolution is not optimal, and the images are distortion free. Combining the targeting and identification of different image data types provide target recognition and environmental characterization and lower false-alarm rates than found from single source imagery. Polarimetric multispectral data from ENVISAT detect environmental degradations, identify waste disposal regions, and enhance flood plain disaster mapping and modeling.
Index Keywords: Environmental Monitoring; High resolutions; Multi-spectral data; Disaster prevention; Image processing; Imaging systems; Radar; Remote sensing; Satellite imagery; Satellites; Sensors; Space optics; Synthetic aperture radar; Synthetic apertures; Target drones; Waste disposal
Correspondence Address: Kincade, K., Alameda, CA, United States; email: kkincade@alamedanet.net

Title: SM-6 missile passes its first test
Authors with affiliations: Newell, C.
Abstract: The US Navy announced the successful completion of the first test of the Standard Missile (SM-6) Extended-Range Active Missile (ERAM). The SM-6 was launched from the navy's Desert Ship test facility that replicates components of the navy's Aegis weapon system. The ERAM intercepted a Northrop Grumman-built BQM-74 aerial drone. the new active seeker technology will increase the SM-6's area of operation by providing illumination through a transmitter instead of relying on shipboard illumination. The active seeker will also give the SM-6 over-the-horizon capabilities, which will allow the missile to follow a target that is beyond the ship's line of sight. The SM-6 also contains self-testing and reprogramming software capabilities that will reduce manual maintenance.
Correspondence Address: Newell, C., Washington, DC, United States

Title: Rockwell Collins eyes further acquisitions
Authors with affiliations: Kemp, D.
Abstract: Rockwell Collins is planning to acquire more companies, in an effort to expand its capabilities significantly. The company has acquired Athena Technologies, the leading manufacturer of unmanned aerial vehicles (UAV). The company announced on 7 April, 2008 that it has completed the acquisition of Athena Technologies. The company produces the GuideStar range of flight-control systems for applications on commercial aircrafts, UAVs, target drones, and missiles. The company's INS/GPS-based flight controllers are used in a wide number of existing UAV systems, including the AAI Shadow, Insitu Scan Eagle, Alenia Sky-X, Elbit/Thales Watchkeeper, and the General Atomics Aeronautical Systems Sky Warrior. Rockwell Collins plans to acquire those companies that will be suitable for its areas of growth.
Correspondence Address: Kemp, D., London, United Kingdom

Title: USAF seeks more agile combat drone
Authors with affiliations: Harrington, C.
Abstract: The US Air Force (USAF) is looking for contractors who are interested in building a new armed drone that is faster, more maneuverable, and better equipped to overcome jamming than the current generation of hunter-killer unmanned aircraft. USAF officials have announced that they will release a request for information (RfI) at the end of May 2008 for the Next Generation Unmanned Aerial System (NG UAS) that is a successor to the MQ-1 Predator and MQ-9 Reaper. The NG UAS is an enhanced hunter-killer unmanned system that would focus on two main missions that include intelligence, surveillance, and reconnaissance (ISR) as well as strike missions in low and medium-threat environments. The USAF said the NG UAS would be able to conduct limited suppression of enemy air defense (SEAD) missions, ensuring that the hunter-killer would be among the first aircraft to fly into contested enemy air space.
Correspondence Address: Harrington, C.United States

Title: Diehl test fires land-based IRIS-T air defence missile variant
Authors with affiliations: McFarlane, D.; Heitman, H.-R.
Abstract: Diehl BGT has completed test firing of a land-based IRIS-T air defense missile on 3 April, 2008 at Overberg Test Range (OTB), near Cape Town, South Africa. The IRIS-T Surface Launched Standard (SLS) short-range missile was fired from a lightweight all-terrain truck. The company has stated that the test was carried out in a representative air defense scenario, successfully producing a direct heat on the target drone. The target was detected and tracked by a Saab Giraffe AMB air defense radar from a distance of more than 10 km. The air defense radar passed on the information to the missile over an integral RF datalink, with its infrared seeker steering in the terminal phase. The test firing of the missile was performed against an EADS 3 Sigma Iris Jet target.
Correspondence Address: McFarlane, D., London, United Kingdom

Title: USAF faces further push to boost UAVs in Afghanistan, Iraq
Authors with affiliations: Harrington, C.
Abstract: The US Air Force (USAF) is facing more pressure for improving the presence of unmanned aircraft in Afghanistan and Iraq after Secretary of Defense Robert Gates bemoaned the tempo of aerial drone deployments in a 21 April speech. Gates criticized the USAF and other services to resist his repeated calls to speeding up the sortie rates of unmanned aerial vehicles (UAV), which are cheaper and offer greater loiter times than manned aircraft. Gates told that services of USAF are not moving aggressively in wartime for providing resources required on the battlefield. He acknowledged that the US military has nearly 5,000 UAVs, a 25-fold rise since the 9/11 attacks, and he also wants to see the number increase more quickly. The Pentagon has set a target to maintain 24 combat air patrols (CAPs) of MQ-1 Predator UAVs in the air at all times by June 2008. He also established a novel Pentagon-wide taskforce for finding ways to more beyond that goat to deploy even more unmanned aircraft.
Correspondence Address: Harrington, C., Washington, DC, United States

Title: Czechs conduct AMRAAM tests on Gripen
Authors with affiliations: Kominek, J.
Abstract: The Czech Air force is conducting operational tests of the Raytheon AIM-120C-5 AMRAAM (Advanced Medium Range Air-to-Air Missile) on board the service's JAS 39C1D Gripen fighter aircraft. The air force took delivery of 24 AIM120C-5 missiles and an undisclosed limited number of training rounds worth $16.7 million from the US Department of Defense in November 2007. It remains unclear whether the MoD will allow the Czech Gripen to deploy to the Baltic states for the NATO Air Policing program in 2009 with its AIM-120C-5 payload. The procurement of the AIM-120C-5 gives a substantial air-to-air advantage to the Czech Gripen fleet. Until recently the aircraft was only armed with the AIM-9M short-range Sidewinder missile. The MoD has procured 100 AIM-9Ms since 2002, with Gripen aircraft successfully launching and hitting drone targets on eight occasions in 2007 during training.
Correspondence Address: Kominek, J., Prague, Czech Republic

Title: USAF reveals airborne live-firing trials of ramjet missile
Abstract: The US Air Force (USAF) has revealed airborne live-firing trials of a US ramjet-powered air-to-surface weapon. ATK and the US Navy (USN), under the Higher-Speed Anti-radiation missile Demonstration (HSAD) program, have combined a ramjet motor with the dual-mode seeker developed for the AGM-88E advanced anti-radiation guided missile (AARGM). The HSAD project that is a parallel effort to the other Suppression of Enemy Air Defences (SEAD) systems evolving in the US aims to produce a new smart very-high-speed and long-range missile to attack enemy air defenses and time-critical targets. An HSAD test vehicle was fired on January 9, 2008 over the White Sands Missile Range by an unmanned QF-4G Phantom full-scale aerial target (FSAT) drone operated by Detachment 1, 82nd Aerial Targets Squadron, based at Holloman Air Force Base. A brief text of this test was revealed by the USAF sources on January 21, 2008, providing few details and without identifying the exact type of weapon involved.

Title: DCNS showcases maritime domain awareness tool
Authors with affiliations: Deseilligny, N.
Abstract: DCNS, a French military shipyard, would present a maritime situational awareness system tool based on the ScanMaris system at the Maritime Systems and Technology (MAST) conference in Genoa, Italy, from November 14-16, 2007. ScanMaris is a system of algorithms using data from legacy systems such as semaphores and radar, together with new technology. It is part of the response to France's decision to rank up the performance within the 200 nautical mile exclusive economic zone with cameras, radars, drones, and satellites.
Correspondence Address: Deseilligny, N., Paris, France

Title: Viper Strike makes combat debut
Authors with affiliations: Hodge, N.
Abstract: The US Army's RQ-%A Hunter drone has made its combat debut as a strike platform, dropping precision munitions on combat missions in Iraq. The army's Hunter unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) had dropped the Viper Strike, a precision glide bomb derived from the Northrop Grumman Brilliant Anti-Tank submunition. The Hunter is a surveillance platform and it can be modified to deliver Viper Strike munitions on certain missions. The Viper Strike was followed by a remote Hellfire engagement by an OH-58D Kiowa Warrior helicopter.
Correspondence Address: Hodge, N., Near Tikrit, Iraq

Title: USAF fast tracks Predator deliveries
Authors with affiliations: Harrington, C.
Abstract: US Air Force (USAF) Chief of Staff General Michael Moseley has ordered the delivery of MQ-1 Predator unmanned aerial vehicles (UAV) and crews to Iraq and to Afghanistan for encouraging the number of combat air patrols flying missions over insurgent strongholds. Gen Moseley has decided to complete the delivery of enough UAVs and crews to provide 21 daily combat air patrols in the Central Command theatre by December 2008. There are currently 12 Predator combat air patrols flying daily in Iraq and Afghanistan but USAF officials will begin growing that number in the near future with crew expansions and drone deployments to accommodate the addition of two more combat air patrols. The USAF also plans to increase the number of available Predator operators from 120 to 160. The most requested of all medium-and high-altitude UAVs in the Central Command theatre, Predator aircraft also use sophisticated sensors and Hellfire missiles to target and attack enemy ground targets.
Correspondence Address: Harrington, C.United States

Title: US Army reveals new details on ACS strategy
Authors with affiliations: Hodge, N.
Abstract: The US Army has provided details about its new acquisition plan for the Aerial Common Sensor (ACS), a next-generation intelligence, surveillance and reconnaissance aircraft. The move has signaled fresh commitment to ACS, which foundered after the service terminated Lockheed Martins $879 million system design and development contract for the ACS in January, 2006. Another focus for the reborn ACS program will be manned-unmanned teaming to link manned aircraft with reconnaissance and surveillance drones. The Lockheed Martin contract was cancelled after the ACS sensor payload proved too large for the Embraer ERJ-145 regional jet selected for the program. The navy's need diverge from the army's requirements for the ACS in range, altitude, and coverage.
Correspondence Address: Hodge, N., Washington, DC, United States

Title: USAF adds SIGINT to Predator/Reaper mission
Authors with affiliations: Trimble, S.
Abstract: The US Air Force (USAF) is planning to upgrade its armed reconnaissance drones to perform as cyber-sleuths. USAF plans to award contract to General Atomics Aeronautical Systems Inc to integrate a Northrop Grumman-made Airborne Signals Intelligence (ASIP) payload and next-generation signals intelligence (SIGINT) payload on the MQ-1L Predator and MQ-9B Reaper unmanned aircraft systems. The US Army is exploring the possibility of ASIP upgrade for the Beech RC-12 Guardrail Common Sensor fleet. It is expected that payload integrated MQ-1L Predator and MQ-9B Reaper would become operational later in 2007.
Correspondence Address: Trimble, S., Washington DC, United States

Title: Need behavioural orientation of dynamos and drones in organizations: A maruti experience
Affiliations: University School of Management Studies, GGS Indraprastha University, Delhi, India
Authors with affiliations: Lather, A.S., University School of Management Studies, GGS Indraprastha University, Delhi, India; Jain, S.
Abstract: Research has recognized the important role of personality in developing and selecting employees and in determining behaviour at workplace. Personality is believed to affect decisionmaking, problem-solving, conflict management, and stress management. This stems from the assumption that role conflicts and organizational stress are also manifestations of the underlying turbulence of one’s personality predispositions. This paper reports the results of the threephase study conducted in Maruti Udyog Limited to understand the different behaviour patterns in workplace. In phase I, secondary data were collected through organizational stress and work motivation questionnaires, and job satisfaction and role conflict scales. In phase II, Dynamos and Drones were identified. Those scoring low on organizational stress, role conflict, and absenteeism and high scores on work motivation, work performance, and job satisfaction were grouped as Dynamos. On the other hand, those obtaining high scores on organizational stress, role conflict, and absenteeism and low scores on work motivation, work performance, and job satisfaction were categorized as Drones. In phase III, the Edwards’ Personal Preference Schedule was administered to Dynamos and Drones to compare the need orientation of their behaviour. In order to examine the difference between the Dynamos and the Drones on various need orientation of their personality, t-test was conducted. The results reveal the following: The Dynamos are significantly higher on achievement, order, and autonomy compared to the Drones. Dynamos prefer to participate in friendly groups and form strong attachments. Dynamo’s high score on endurance shows that they keep pursuing a job till it is complete. The drones are significantly higher on aggression and heterosexuality resulting in poor interpersonal relationship. There is no difference between the Dynamos and the Drones on deference, exhibition, interception, dominance, abasement, and change. In order to grow and be successful, an organization therefore needs a workforce consisting of more Dynamos. And, to be a dynamo, one should have the need personality orientation of order, endurance, and achievement which accounts for one's desire to give his best, to be successful, plan work, and stick to the job till the end. The author also stresses upon the need orientation of affiliation, succorance, and nurturance which together form the key ingredients for building interpersonally sensitive relationship. © 2007 SAGE Publications.
Author Keywords: Achievement; Dynamos and drones; Endurance; Need orientation; Nurturance; Succorance

Title: IMI pushes Delilah to European navies
Authors with affiliations: Ben-David, A.
Abstract: The Israel Air Force (IAF) has used the Israel Military Industries (IMI) Delilah air-to-surface standoff missile system in combat. The air-launched Delilah was deployed by IAF F-16D multirole fighter aircraft during the Israel Defense Force's Operation 'Change Direction' in Lebanon. IMI is now launching a marketing effort aimed at the European naval market, offering the air-launched version of the Delilah, with a 150 km range. IMI has stated that several European navies are examining the Delilah as their next-generation long-range, air-launched, anti-surface warfare weapon. The Delilah can be fitted with interchangeable forward-looking infra-red/color charge-coupled device or electro-optical seekers for target acquisition and guidance. It is capable of identifying targets at ranges of up to 16 km with auto-tracking capability.
Index Keywords: Anti-surface warfare weapons; Israel Air Force (IAF); Israel Military Industries (IMI); Charge coupled devices; Electrooptical devices; Guns (armament); Marine engineering; Military operations; Target drones; Marine missiles
Correspondence Address: Ben-David, A., Tel Aviv, Israel

Title: US Navy calls for low cost drones for swarming practice
Authors with affiliations: Harrington, C.
Abstract: The US Navy requires low-cost, small, unmanned systems for simulating the threat of asymmetric attacks. These systems will enable simulating swarming unmanned aircrafts that drop bombs or nerve agents on US ships or ground troops. These systems will be engaged in the target practice and weapons testing. The development of an unmanned systems that communicate with other unmanned systems around it seems to be difficult. Some companies have started developing unmanned systems that can be used in groups to simulate a swarming attack on a ship. Lockheed Martin's Skunkworks unveiled an unmanned system, which is a small and can fly at an altitude between 50 ft and 15,000 ft at 200-300 kt. Advanced Composite Manufacturing (ACM) has also created a target drone,which is 368 cm-wide and 370 cm-long and can fly at a maximum average speed of 170-180 mph. Northrop Grumman is another company that is a major player in the development of military target.
Index Keywords: Swarming attack; Unmanned aircrafts; Weapons testing; Bombs (ordnance); Computer crime; Computer simulation; Target drones; Unmanned vehicles; Marine engineering
Correspondence Address: Harrington, C., Panama City, FL, United States

Title: Warrior armament is revised to align with FRES
Authors with affiliations: Foss, C.F.
Abstract: The UK Ministry of Defence has decided to merge the weapon station selected for WLIP with the scout version of the projected Fuure Rapid Effect System (FRES). Additional weapons and ammunition is expected to be procured at lower unit costs, while providing the user with improved training and logistic support. The Joint WLIP IPT is expected to undertake a structured and quantitative assessment that would result in a downselect by early December 2006. Operational analysis demonstrated that larger calibers have a clear advantage in urban operations as well as increasing platform survivability with the ability to engage targets at longer ranges. The key user requirements for WLIP, including the ability to engage moving targets out to a range of 2,000 m, while the platform is moving under and night condition.
Index Keywords: Future Rapid Effect System (FRES); Logistic support; Operational analysis; Ammunition; Command and control systems; Costs; Logistics; Military operations; Operations research; Personnel training; Target drones; Guns (armament)
Correspondence Address: Foss, C.F., London, United Kingdom

Title: CAS training calls on warfighting experience
Authors with affiliations: Harrington, C.
Abstract: The US pilots and infantry are planning to practice the intricate co-ordination needed for precision air strikes in Iraq and Afganistan. The US Air Force (USAF), US Marine Corps (USMC), US Navy (USN) and US Army personnel attacked cinder blocks and burnout vehicles at a bombing range in Avon Park, Florida, during an exercise to test their ability. The exercise, dubbed 'Atlantic Strike IV', practiced calling in airstrikes on insurgents and insurgent hide-outs in a crowded urban environment. The exercises were designed by troops returning from Iraq and Afganistan to make it realistic. Drills were conducted every two hours during daylight and they involved a US convoy running through the mock town where they faced simulated improvised explosive devices. The JTACs used a dedicated channel to send targeting co-ordinates to an air-support operations center (ASOC), which prioritized the requests and assigned aircraft to strike the targets.
Index Keywords: Air-support operations center (ASOC); US Air Force (USAF); US Marine Corps (USMC); Aircraft mockups; Fighter aircraft; Personnel training; Target drones; Military operations
Correspondence Address: Harrington, C., Avon Park, FL, United States

Title: First European MALE UAV makes successful flight
Authors with affiliations: Ben-David, A.
Abstract: The Systeme Interimaire de Drone (SIDM) medium-altitude long-endurance (MALE) unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) being developed for the French Ministry of Defenceby EADS and Israel Aircraft Industries (IAI) has successfully completed its first flight on September 11, 2006. The flight was operated from a SIDM ground station, satellite communication, and integral command-and-control functions. The SIDM, also known as Eagle 1, is based on IAI's Heron UAV and has been modified for French Air Force requirement. It is equipped with an IAI Tamam electro-optic/infra-red payload with laser designator, Elta's EL/M-2005 synthetic aperture radar and Insec's satellite communication system. The SIDM is capable of carrying 250 kg in payload, providing 24-hours endurance at a maximum altitude of 30,000 ft. EADS and IAI jointly developed the SIDM in Israel under a EUR40 million contract with France.
Index Keywords: Payload; Systeme Interimaire de Drone (SIDM); Unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV); Contracts; Flight dynamics; Military operations; Satellite communication systems; Synthetic aperture radar; Unmanned vehicles
Correspondence Address: Ben-David, A., Tel Aviv, Israel

Title: DoD group seeks to give autonomy to armed drones
Authors with affiliations: Trimble, S.
Abstract: A US Department of Defense (DoD) is making a plan to give unmanned systems the authority to fire on enemy weapon systems. A proposal published in September, 2006, will give 'armed autono-mous systems' the authority to shoot to destroy hostile weapon systems but not suspected combatants. Accordingly in September, 2006, any people killed or injured in the attack will be considered the collateral damage of a successful strike on a legitimate target. The proposals rose from John S Canning's, a chief engineer at the Naval Surface Warfare Center, work with the Defense Safety Working Group, a body of the office of acquisition, technology and logistics within the Office of the Secretary of Defense. The group determined that the DoD shall review the existing policy which welds a human operator to each armed unmanned system, even as their numbers populating each of the air, ground, and naval domains grows.
Index Keywords: Defense Safety Working Group; Department of Defense (DoD); Secretary of Defense; Guns (armament); Naval vessels; Personnel; Public policy; Unmanned vehicles; Military operations
Correspondence Address: Trimble, S., Washington, DC, United States

Title: US Army opens CROWS requirement to competition
Authors with affiliations: Gourley, S.R.
Abstract: The US army has opened a competitive procurement for its future common remotely-operated weapon station (CROWS) requirement. The CROWS requirement originally emerged from the US army military police community, but was embraced for broader service application. The M101 CROWS enables under-armor/remote operation of a variety of weapons, including the MK19 40 mm grenade machine gun, the M2 0.50-cal machine gun, the M240B 7.62 mm machine gun, and the M249 5.56 mm squad automatic weapon. The system comprises a two-axis stabilized mount containing acquisition and first-burst target engagement. In addition to the M101 CROWS, the army has also been fielding quantities of the M151 protector remote weapon station (RWS) for use on the Stryker family of vehicles manufactured by Kongsberg Protech. Amendments have extended the CROWS proposal closing date to November 27, 2007.
Index Keywords: Common remotely operated weapon station (CROWS); Kongsberg Protech (CO); Machine guns; Remote weapon station (RWS); Civil defense; Ordnance; Personnel; Remote control; Target drones; Military operations
Correspondence Address: Gourley, S.R., CA, United States

Title: US in bid to get laser system to Iraq quickly
Authors with affiliations: Harrington, C.
Abstract: The US Office of Force Transformation (OFT) is undertaking a major effort inside the US department of Defence (DoD) to secure millions of dollars to deploy a new laser-based system to Iraq by second half of 2008. The OFT needs around USD100million over the next two years to deploy its Tactical Relay Mirror System (TRMS) in Iraq, where it could be used to destroy improvised explosive devices (IEDs), hostile vehicles and insurgents on the ground in hard-to-reach areas. OFT officials also plan to spend some of their own FY07 budget, which stands around USD20 million. The TRMS system is designed to fire a relatively low-power laser - in the 15 kW to 25 Kw range - off mirrors housed on a tethered aerostat, redirecting the laser toward ground targets.
Index Keywords: Improvised explosive devices (IEDs); Laser-based system; Office of Force Transformation (OFT); Tactical Relay Mirror System (TRMS); Budget control; Explosives; Laser applications; Military vehicles; Mirrors; Target drones; Military operations
Correspondence Address: Harrington, C., Washington, DC, United States

Title: LJDAM successfully hits moving target
Authors with affiliations: Hughes, R.
Abstract: Boeing has successfully tested its Laser Joint Direct Attack Munition (LJDAM) weapon system against a moving target. The testing was done at Eglin Air Force Base, Florida, on 30 June, 2006, where a US Air Force F-16 flying at 20,000 feet scored a direct hit on an armored personnel carrier (APC) moving at 46 km/h. JDAM is a low-cost guidance kit that converts existing unguided free-fall bombs into near-precision guided 'smart' weapons. The JDAM kit, produced by Boeing, comprises a tail section containing a GPS/INS and body strakes for additional stability and lift. LJDAM adds a modular sensor kit that can be easily installed in the field to the front of existing JDAM weapons, and it will be integrated with the 500 lb GBU-38 JDAM. Boeing will complete its development of the 500 lb LJDAM later in 2006 with initial production deliveries planned to begin as early as 2007.
Index Keywords: Armored personnel carrier (APC); Laser Joint Direct Attack Munition (LJDAM); Low-cost guidance kit; Armor; Bombs (ordnance); Equipment testing; Global positioning system; Military equipment; Planning; Target drones
Correspondence Address: Hughes, R., London, United Kingdom

Title: Contract signed for Typhoon ground attack
Authors with affiliations: Kemp, D.
Abstract: The UK Royal Air Force (RAF) has signed a contract with the NATO Eurofighter and Tornado Management Agency (NETMA) under which Eurofighter GmbH will provide RAF, the software needed to provide RAF Eurofighter Typhoon fighter with an austere ground-attack capability. The upgrade will allow the RAF to operate the Rafael Armament Development Authority Litening III laser designator pods and self-designating Enhanced Paveway II dual-mode guided bombs. It has been stated that the changes to create an austere capability in Tranche 1 Block 5 aircraft were mainly software related but also needed some hardware changes to enable the aircraft to carry and operate Litening III. The austere capability will make the UK the first country to operate the Eurofighter with an advanced ground-attack capability in which an aircraft can designate its own targets. The UK's Tranche 1 Block 1, 2 and 2B aircraft will need a more substantial upgrade, including changes to wiring, components and computing.
Index Keywords: Attack capability; Dual-mode guided bombs; Ground attack; Laser designator pods; Bombs (ordnance); Computer software; Fighter aircraft; Military equipment; Military operations; Target drones; Contracts
Correspondence Address: Kemp, D., London, United Kingdom

Title: US Army considers mass purchase of Trijicon gunsights
Authors with affiliations: White, A.
Abstract: The US Army is considering for a mass purchase of Trijicon Advanced Combat Optical Gunsights (ACOG) to equip each of its M16 weapon systems. The Army has already placed a preliminary order with sight specialist Trijicon for 7700 TA31 Rifle Combat Optics (RCO) worth between USD610 and USD 1450 each, which would be delivered in the second half of 2006 for evaluation purposes. Trijicon also won a USD660 million contract to provide a modified version of the ACOG to the USMC. The army has an official magnified combat optic program in which it plans to purchase a substantial quantity of magnified optics. The RCO comprises quick target acquisition for close-quarter combat, enhanced target identification and dual illumination technology using a combination of fiber optics and self-luminous tritium. Other features include dual illustrated reticle, enhanced adjuster caps and chevron reticle and crosshair.
Index Keywords: Close-quarter combat; Rifle Combat Optics (RCO); Self-luminous tritium; Weapon systems; Contracts; Fiber optics; Optics; Target drones; Gunsights
Correspondence Address: White, A., London, United Kingdom

Title: Demand for drones soars pending USMC award
Authors with affiliations: Trimble, S.
Abstract: A new class of small unmanned unmanned aircraft systems that operate at low altitude for 24 hour periods will be included in the US military's USD 2 billion annual spending on drones. The contract award is expected in August for the US Marine Corps Tier II UAS demonstrator. For the USMC, the Tier II programme seeks to fill a gap for a long endurance, close-range UAS to support regiment-level needs for surveillance, reconnaissance and communications relay. At a broader level, the high cost of operating medium-altitude, long endurance UAS also is driving the appeal for relatively inexpensive low altitude drones with similar endurance. Five industry teams have formed to submit bids for the Tier II demonstrator contract, which include AAI/Aerosonde Mk 4, the Advanced Ceramics Research Silver Fox, The BAE Systems Sky Lynx, the Boeing/Insitu Group Scan Eagle and the Northrop Grumman/Swift Engineering Killer Bee. Among the competitors, Northrop Grumman's Killer Bee flying wing design stands out as perhaps the most conceptually ambitious.
Index Keywords: BAE Systems (CO); Communications relay; Operating medium-altitude; Unmanned aircraft; Aircraft; Contracts; Costs; Military operations; Target drones; Unmanned vehicles
Correspondence Address: Trimble, S., Washington, DC, United States

Title: OPINION - Missile defence: A necessity not a luxury
Affiliations: Missile Defence Agency
Authors with affiliations: Holly, J., Missile Defence Agency
Abstract: The missile launches by the North Korea has reinforced the necessity and the urgency of evolving the missile defense system to protect both the homeland and the deployed forces. The decision of the country to launch in the face of strong diplomatic efforts and threats of sanction from multiple countries reinforces the unpredictability of the regime. It is found that most tests are single events conducted in a one-to-one scenario due to cost and range constraints. It is believed that the operational commanders in an actual attack can employ multiple interceptors against a single target. It is suggested that the return of a single intercept of an inbound ballistic missile is clearly worth the cost in lives saved as well as avoidance of adverse economic impact.
Index Keywords: Ballistics; Launching; Military operations; Target drones; Defense system; Range constraints; Missiles
Correspondence Address: Holly, J.; Missile Defence Agency

Title: Sri Lankan ceasefire slips
Authors with affiliations: Athas, I.
Abstract: A fragile four-year ceasefire is under threat in the aftermath of an audacious suicide bombing that targeted Sri Lankan Army Chief Lieutenant General Sarath Fonseka on 25 April, 2006. There are fears that the attack will strained Ceasefire Agreement (CFA) between the Sri Lankan government and Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE). A woman suicide bomber penetrated the highly fortified Sri Lankan Army Headquarter by passing herself as a pregnant woman visiting the military hospital's regular maternity clinic. However, the bulges hid a lethal mix of explosives and steel balls strapped to her stomach and chest. However, both Colombo and the LTTE have repeatedly asserted their commitment to the CFA, while civilians on both sides are clearly weary of conflict.
Index Keywords: Ceasefire Agreement (CFA); Maternity clinic; Steel balls; Suicide bombing; Civil defense; Explosives; Hospitals; Medical problems; Military operations; Target drones; Bombing
Correspondence Address: Athas, I., Colombo, Sri Lanka

Title: VL Mica chalks up naval success
Authors with affiliations: Brown, N.
Abstract: An MBDA Vertical Launch (VL) Mica missile successfully completed its first vertical launch and engagement from a navy-specific launcher at the Centre d'Essai de Lancement des Missiles facility in southwest France in April, 2006. The missile exited the launcher correctly before punting over to home in on a very low-level target using its integral infra-red seeker in a lock-on-after-launch mode to guide the missile in to impact on the drone 10 km away. The program is conducted under a French tri-service requirement for a naval and land-based medium range air defense system. MBDA has long claimed foreign interest in the program and the latest launch was apparently attended by a delegation from an interested foreign navy.
Index Keywords: Air defense systems; Integral infra-red seeker; Navy-specific launcher; Vertical launch; Civil defense; International cooperation; Launching; Marine missiles; Military aircraft; Target drones; Military engineering
Correspondence Address: Brown, N., London, United Kingdom

Title: Indian Navy to put Barak-1 on most warships
Authors with affiliations: Bedi, R.
Abstract: The Indian Navy is planning to equip most of its surface warships with the Barak-1 air-defense missile. The Barak-1 system uses command-to-line-of-sight radar guidance to steer the missile over an 8-10 km range to intercept incoming missiles, hostile aircraft and unmanned drones. Barak-1 launchers are currently operational on seven IN platforms which includes the aircraft carrier INS Viraat, two Type 15 Delhi-class destroyers, two Type 16 Godavari-class frigates and two Rajput-class destroyers. The IN turned to the Barak missile system after India's Defence Research and Development Organisation (DRDO) failed, after some two decades of effort to develop the quick-reaction, low-altitude surface-to-air Trishul missile.
Index Keywords: Barak-1 air-defense missile; Defence Research and Development Organisation (DRDO); Surface-to-air Trishul missile; Unmanned drones; Aircraft; Missiles; Planning; Unmanned vehicles; Warships
Correspondence Address: Bedi, R., New Delhi, India

Title: Canadian army sets sights on small UAV
Authors with affiliations: Hobson, S.
Abstract: The Canadian Forces Mobile Command is expected to acquire a small drone system as part of its strategy to get several unmanned aerial vehicles (UAV). The army is planning to acquire a small UAV to meet the intelligence, surveillance, and reconnaissance (ISR) requirements. It is seeking for a system that would be operated by a 16-soldier troop and would be capable of 24-hour operations that would prospectively extend upto 36 hours continuously. The entire system consisting of the ground control station, ground data terminal, air vehicles, and launch and recovery elements should fit on a single light support vehicle. The UAV should have a 30 km range with an endurance of at least six hours with payload. It would carry optical and infra-red sensors along with a laser designator and should be able to locate a target within a distance of 50 m. The army is interested to acquire the Boeing/Insitu ScanEagle and Malat I-View 50 and Elbit Systems Skylark 2 of the Israel Aircraft Industries.
Index Keywords: Ground control station; Ground data terminal; Single light support vehicles; Unmanned aerial vehicles (UAV); Infrared radiation; Military operations; Reconnaissance aircraft; Sensors; Space surveillance; Target drones; Unmanned vehicles
Correspondence Address: Hobson, S., Ottawa, Canada

Title: Air-to-ground network advances into hardware development stage
Authors with affiliations: Trimble, S.
Abstract: Rockwell Collins has been awarded the lead role in developing a critical five-node network intended to be on the primary link for ground troops needing to request air strikes or obtain airborne reconnaisance imagery. With this regard, Quint Networking Technology (QNT) is to create afordable datalink technologies that can be used to share information between any two or more of five nodes aircraft cokpits, airborne precision munitions, tactical reconnaissance drones, unmanned combat air veicles and dismounted ground troops. The dual-channel, high-bandwidth network would be used to improve on the narrowband links including L-3 Communications Rover terminals to transmit electro-optical camera imagery from aircrafts to ground controllers.
Index Keywords: Datalink technologies; Ground troops; Quint Networking Technology (QNT); Tactical reconnaissance drones; Bandwidth; Cameras; Ground operations; Imaging systems; Military aircraft; Military communications; Contracts
Correspondence Address: Trimble, S., Washington, DC, United States

Title: IDF loses Skylark UAV in West Bank crash
Authors with affiliations: David, A.B.
Abstract: An Elbit Systems Skylark mini unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) crashed on 20 February, 2006 on a house in the West Bank city of Nablus during an Israel Defense Force (IDF) operation. The Skylark was operated by a special force unit on a reconnaissance mission, during an arrest operation in Nablus. The operators lost control of the mini UAV, which began descending and crashed on a roof at the Balata Refugee Camp, without causing any injuries or damage. Palestanians who rushed to the crashed site dismantled the remains of the drone and its payload. .
Index Keywords: Arrest operation; Mini unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV); Reconnaissance; Aviation; Military operations; Target drones; Unmanned vehicles
Correspondence Address: David, A.B., Tel-Aviv, Israel

Title: Asian Aerospace 2004: Eagle 2 drone set for first flight
Abstract: The prototype of the Eagle 2 unmanned air vehicle (UAV) is scheduled to make its first flight "by the second half of next year", according to representatives of the Malat Division of Israel Aircraft Industries (IAI) and EADS that is developing a successor to the original Eagle. The Eagle performed the first-ever UAV flight demonstration as part of a scheduled flying display at Asian Aerospace 2004 on 23 February. The flight clearance followed demonstrations of the system in Canada, Sweden and the US. © 2005 Jane's Information Group. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Exhibitions; Air show; Exhibitors; Organizers; Aerospace applications

Title: Set pieces
Authors with affiliations: Wilson, I.
Abstract: Key elements in the stitched and woven textiles of Matthew Harris are folklore and experimental music. His affinity for utilitarian ingredients and built up surfaces through patching and darning, stitching and embroidery is described, and the joining and juxtaposing of cloths with different designs. His experimental work at Goldsmiths College is detailed, and his OSS Cloth work, related to the hobbyhorse. The techniques involved are explored. Criss Cross, three works which may increase in the future is made on unbleached builder's dust-sheet with painting, dyeing and layering in other fabrics. The Gruppen works are examined with drawing, making and music contributing, resulting from his friendship with conductor Martin Brabbins. The intricate construction of the work is detailed, leading the eye through the fabric and paper and its many subtleties. Work on his next project has been triggered by Songs, Drones and Refrains of Death by American composer George Crumb and the philosophy and intentions behind the work are described, including bigger blocks of colour and the application of principles and practices of distillation.
Index Keywords: embroidery; stitch; textile art; woven fabric
